Bahrain I wish to approach you on a subject in which, I think, all offices and departments in Manamah are, to a greater or less degree, interested. I refer to the problem of accommodation for our clerical staff. 2. As you know, it is at present not at all easy for a clerk, whether he be in the employ of the Agency or of the Bahrain Government, to obtain suitable accommodation for himself and his family (if he is married) at a rental which his rate of salary enables him to pay. The office clerk is, of course, a comparatively new comer to Bahrain - at least, in such numbers as at present - and neither the house of the well-to-do merchant nor the hut of the pearl diver is suitable for him. I think, therefore, that as capital is now available for useful enterprises, it is a fit opportunity for me to ask you to consider whether the Bahrain Government can do something to help these (very essential) members of our community. 3. To enable me to give you something concrete as a basis, I took the opportunity of having an informal talk with Mr. Mohammad Jaffarj as a result of which I am convinced that the construction of inexpensive houses for the clerical staffs can be a profitable investment, as well as a progressive measure. I understood from him that small houses, suitable for occupation by a married family or two bachelors could probably be constructed in pairs at a cost of Rs. 10,000/- for each pair and that for/that for this figure it should be possible to provide water and sanitation* A monthly rental of 30/- would therefore give a return of Mtfeer more than 7% and there would be no difficulty in ensuring that the houses would be continuously occupied 9 as clerks would normally take over accommodation from their predecessors* 4* It would seem to be advantageous and would certainly be preferred by the clerks 9 if the houses could be constructed in a fairly compact areai rather than scattered about the town* It would make for ease and economy of construction* and there ls y fortunately, no lack of suitable sites for such a 'mohalla” • 5* Should* however* the Bahrain Government be averse to initiating the scheme themselves* they might consider encouraging a contractor to undertake it* possibly by granting a favourable lease of the ground required* 6* I shall be interested* therefore* to hear your views on this proposal* Officiating Political Agent,GOVERNMENT OF BAHRAIN. ©> $ No. 0 f 1357 Office of the adviser to the Governmeirt, Bahrain Dated,17th J/ihani, 1357 August 14, 1$38. May I invite a reference to your No:1218-18/8 of the 10th August 1938; which relates to accomodation in Bahrain for subordinates of clerical standing. 2. It is agreed that the local conditions are as you state; and for some time the Adviser has had in mind the initiation of a building scheme on the lines of an Indian Cantonment. In fact careful consideration was given to this idea at the time when the Budget for the current year was in preparation. 3. It was found, however, that the Governments build ing programme for the public service, such as the Dispen sary, Hospitals, Schools, and Customs pier,would keep the P.W.D. fully occupied for the whole Jrear, even with its increased staff; and, although the proposal has the Adviser sympathetic consideration, he is unable to undertake any new scheme until these works are finished. 4. It is thought, however, that if this prpposal were suggested by Yourself to certain local landowners, such as Shaikh Mustafa bin Abdul Latif, or Hussain Yateem, these persons would be sufficiently enterprising to erest pre mises suitable for occupancy by Bahrain foreign non- European/. .I have examined Farouk Rouse and submit two rough sketches from memory of the upper floor and ground floor respectively. Many of the rooms on the ground floor v/ere occupied by the caretaker, his friends, and their families, and were not inspected. This applies also to some of the store rooms. The orientation is approximate. There are five rooms on the upper floor. The room at the end of the centre passage measures roughly 26 x 17 x 15 feet, and the others 20 x 20 'x 15 feet. There are several doors to each room though only a few are shown in the sketch, and they are well lighted. (One of the passages has been roughly boarded up and fitted with a door to make a 6 th room.) All the rooms are in need of whitewashing and minor repairs to the flooring. Entering from the porch I could not inspect the rooms to the right of the main passage but was told that they are in fair condition. The others v/ere in a dilapidated state and require extensive repairs. The largest room measured 63 x20 £ 15 feet. It has a low cement block at one end rurining across most of the width of the room which, I understand used to serve as a rations counter. This room is in slightly better condition than the rooms behind it. The rooms on the upper floor would make good bachelor accommodation, though more latrines and bath rooms would have to be built. The kitchen accommodation could be used for this purpose and’kitchens provided fop the bachelors in the back courtyard. This is a large courtyard measuring 140 x 116 feet. Accommodation for two or possibly three families could be provided in the ground floor. I did not notice any latrines on this floor, but there is a large open kitchen attached to one side of the building and the only water tank in the building is on this floor. It will be seen that there is enough accommodation for all the clerks of this Agency in Farouk Rouse. The front courtyard is even larger than the back yard and could accommo date tennis and badminton courts. if all the bachelor accom modation were not required a room could be provided on the upper floor for the Agency Club. titleInfo.title: ‘File 18/13 I. Buildings: Accommodation for Agency Clerical Staff’

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 72; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-35; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: The file contains papers, mostly correspondence, relating to accommodation for Bahrain Political Agency clerical staff, including correspondence regarding the flat formerly used by the Public Relations Offices.The file includes three documents in Arabic, including correspondence between the Ruler of Bahrain and the Political Agent, Bahrain.The other correspondence is largely between the Political Agent, Bahrain, and the following: the Acting Adviser to the Government of Bahrain; Haji Khalil bin Ebrahim Kanoo; and the Political Residency in the Persian Gulf, at Bahrain.Detailed file notes are found on folios 59 to 69.
